qas.question: What was the primary use of a phonographic disc record?
Which year did vinyl records leave the main steam media market?
From the 1990s to 2010s who was the primary consumer of vinyl records?
Approximately how many phonograph records were sold in 2014?
What is the niche market of phonograph record fans known as?

context: The phonograph disc record was the primary medium used for <a0_0>music reproduction<a0_0/> until late in the 20th century, replacing the phonograph cylinder record–with which it had co-existed from the late 1880s through to the 1920s–by the late 1920s. Records retained the largest market share even when new formats such as compact cassette were mass-marketed. By the late 1980s, digital media, in the form of the compact disc, had gained a larger market share, and the vinyl record left the mainstream in <a1_0>1991<a1_0/>. From the 1990s to the 2010s, records continued to be manufactured and sold on a much smaller scale, and were especially used by <a2_0>disc jockeys (DJ)s<a2_0/>, released by artists in some genres, and listened to by a niche market of <a4_0>audiophiles<a4_0/>. The phonograph record has made a niche resurgence in the early 21st century – <a3_0>9.2 million<a3_0/> records were sold in the U.S. in 2014, a 260% increase since 2009. Likewise, in the UK sales have increased five-fold from 2009 to 2014.
